conclusion: The problem involves calculating the speed of an elevator at t=60s using the acceleration-time diagram.
To find the speed at t=60s, analyze the acceleration-time diagram and determine its effect on velocity.
The diagram shows acceleration (a) in m/s² plotted against time (t) in seconds, with red-shaded areas representing the change in velocity.
From t=0 to t=1s, acceleration increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s².
From t=1s to t=4s, acceleration is constant at 2 m/s².
From t=4s to t=5s, acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0.
From t=5s to t=55s, acceleration is zero.
From t=55s to t=56s, acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -2 m/s².
From t=56s to t=59s, acceleration is constant at -2 m/s².
From t=59s to t=60s, acceleration increases linearly from -2 m/s² to 0.
The change in velocity (Δv) equals the area under the acceleration-time curve.
From t=0 to t=1s, the area under the curve is (1/2) × 1s × 2m/s² = 1 m/s.
From t=1s to t=4s, the area under the curve is 3s × 2m/s² = 6 m/s.
From t=4s to t=5s, the area under the curve is (1/2) × 1s × 2m/s² = 1 m/s.
From t=5s to t=55s, the area under the curve is 0 (no acceleration).
From t=55s to t=56s, the area under the curve is (1/2) × 1s × (-2m/s²) = -1 m/s.
From t=56s to t=59s, the area under the curve is 3s × (-2m/s²) = -6 m/s.
From t=59s to t=60s, the area under the curve is (1/2) × 1s × (-2m/s²) = -1 m/s.
